abstracts.content:
FEMALE POISONERS: A PROVINCIAL NETWORK OF MARITICIDES IN SEVENTEENTH-CENTURY LESSER POLAND:
Italy in the 17th century saw the spread of an odourless, colourless and tasteless arsenic-based poison called Aqua Tofana. From the very beginning, it was a substance produced and distributed within women’s supporting networks, and the potential victims of this poison would be the husbands of women who did decide to use it. However, no estimate can be made as to the number of actual victims of this female poisoning of husbands. Trials of women accused of this crime were sporadic, but caused extremely strong social panics triggered by fear of sexual anarchy and an erosion of patriarchal power. The myth of the very existence of female ‘husband poisoner’ circles existed in many European countries up to the first half of the 20th century across all social groups. State regulation of the circulation of poisons, especially arsenic, gradually reduced the problem to socially marginal circles, such as peasants. This article analyses in detail the trial of three women accused of taking part in a conspiracy to poison their husbands with arsenic, which took place in 1659 in the town of Nowy Wiśnicz, Lesser Poland. The defendants came from an artisanal small-town or rural environment. The analysis reveals features typical of the pan-European stereotype of female poisoners: unresolvable marital conflicts, cooperation between women in the familial circle to obtain poison and to conceal crime, the role of a local sorceress in the preparation of the potion, the association of the poisoning practice with a witchcraft belief. The records of the trial also make it possible to trace the social reaction to the alleged poisoning of husbands, the functioning perceptions about correct and incorrect conjugal relations, and the underlying awareness of the threat posed by the alleged female mariticides solidarity circles.
